sect1.title: Installing &cilium;

warning.title: Tech Preview
warning.para: Please note &cilium; is currently only a tech preview. It will work but is not officially supported.

sect1.para: &kube; allows to choose one of many available Network Plugins, which usually come in form of &cni; plugins.

&kube; provides a specification called &net_pols; which define how groups of pods are allowed to communicate with each other and with other network endpoints. &net_pols; are clustered firewall rules defined with &kube; concepts. But &kube; does not provide &net_pols; implementation on its own.
&productname; provides another &cni; plugin as a tech preview feature - &cilium; - which supports &net_pols;.

The main characteristic of &cilium; is using &ebpf; (extended Berkeley Packet Filter) as a mechanism for filtering incoming and outgoing packets in containers. &ebpf; is a bytecode interpreter inside Linux kernel which allows to write programs to analyze, filter network packets and to monitor system function calls. &cilium; translates &net_pols; into &ebpf; programs which are loaded into the kernel.
This section shows how to set up &cilium; on &productname; and check whether it is working.

sect2.title: Disclaimers

important.para: This document describes a temporary way of &cilium; deployment. Before releasing &productname; v4, &cilium; deployment will be supported by &dashboard;.

sect2.para: All steps need to be done before the cluster is deployed with &dashboard;.
The current implementation of &cilium; deployment in &productname; does not allow yet to use L7 network policies (only L3 and L4).

sect2.title: Deploying the cluster
sect2.para: After the successful reboot, go to &dashboard; web interface and proceed with the deployment of the cluster. Feel free to change the networking settings on the bootstrap page (i.e. CIDR); all these settings are going to be used by &cilium;.

sect2.title: Checking whether &cilium; works
sect2.para: This section is based on the official &cilium; documentation which provides an example for checking &net_pols; in &cilium;.
It comes with three microservices applications inspired by Star Wars:

listitem.para: An HTTP webservice, which is exposed as a Kubernetes Service. It provides landing services to the Empire's spaceships which can request a landing.
A pod which serves as a landing-request client. It's Empire's ship.
A pod which serves as a landing-request client. It's Alliance's ship.

procedure.title: Checking whether &cilium; works with Star Wars microservices

step.para: Deploy Star Wars applications with the following command:
step.screen: &prompt.root;kubectl create -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/cilium/cilium/v1.2/examples/minikube/http-sw-app.yaml service/deathstar created deployment.extensions/deathstar created pod/tiefighter created pod/xwing created

step.para: Check the status of pods and services, wait until they are all ready.
step.screen:
&prompt.root;kubectl get pods,svc NAME READY STATUS RESTARTS AGE pod/deathstar-6fb5694d48-5hmds 1/1 Running 0 107s pod/deathstar-6fb5694d48-fhf65 1/1 Running 0 107s pod/tiefighter 1/1 Running 0 107s pod/xwing 1/1 Running 0 107s
NAME TYPE CLUSTER-IP EXTERNAL-IP PORT(S) AGE service/deathstar ClusterIP 10.96.110.8 <none> 80/TCP 107s service/kubernetes ClusterIP 10.96.0.1 <none> 443/TCP 3m53s

step.para: Check whether both tiefighter and xwing are allowed to connect to deathstar and acces the API. They should, because there was no &net_pol; applied yet.
step.screen: &prompt.root;kubectl exec xwing -- curl -s -XPOST deathstar.default.svc.cluster.local/v1/request-landing Ship landed &prompt.root;kubectl exec tiefighter -- curl -s -XPOST deathstar.default.svc.cluster.local/v1/request-landing Ship landed

step.para: Apply the &net_pol; which allows to connect to deathstar only from endpoints which have label org: empire.
Now try to connect to deathstar from tiefighter. It should work.
And then try to connect to deathstar from xwing. The request shold hang forever and pressing Control-C will be needed to kill the curl request.

sect2.para: &cilium; is up and running properly when the previous steps all completed except the last one; which should be forbidden by the policy.
